text: hi and welcome to getting started with
fleet hub for aws iot device management
my name is greg breen and i'm an iot
specialist solutions architect
with aws today i'll be talking about
fleet hub
a feature of aws iot device management
that enables you to visualize your
device fleet through a single dashboard
streamline workflows with alarms and
actions integrate with our aws iot
services
and manage your fleet with no code all
through a fully managed web application
that you can generate in minutes
in this video part one of two i'll show
you how to create the web application
and give you a quick tour of the app
in the next video i'll show you how to
start managing your fleet through the
fleet hub web application
to follow along we'll assume you have
aws
sso or single sign-on already set up
by using sso fleet hub users don't need
to be developers in the aws
management console with their own iam
user accounts
instead you can use sso for operational
staff
and iam for developers a clear
separation of concerns
for this demo we'll also need devices
connected configured and
indexed using fleet indexing if you
don't already know about fleet indexing
please watch the getting started with
fleet indexing video
the devices i'll use in this demo
already have attributes and shadows
that contain device information such as
serial number
firmware version and accelerometer
readings
in this demo i'll be managing a small
fleet of physical devices here on my
desk
these are a collection of devices from
the aws partner device catalog
as well as commonly acquired parts such
as a raspberry pi
it's a diverse set of devices spanning
tcpip
connectivity lorawan friatos linux
aws iot greengrass and more
fleet hub features such as alarms and
jobs will be demonstrated with these
real devices
therefore this demo gives you insight
into how fleet hub handles and renders
different device types
in the aws console on the things tab
we can see all the things i've created
for these physical devices
so they can connect to aws iot
note that my raspberry pi appears twice
because it's running two device
softwares
greengrass version 2 and aws iot
device client which is an aws iot
reference implementation the four
stm32ip
free rtos devices and the two lorawan
devices
are configured to publish shadow updates
to report firmware version and
accelerometer readings
now i go to the fleet hub tab then
applications
and create application the first step is
to set up single sign-on using the aws
sso service if you haven't already
enabled sso
in your account you'll be prompted to do
so since i already have
i can proceed to next
step two is to configure your fleet
indexing settings fleet hub uses fleet
indexing as one of its core components
to help you search for
organize and filter your devices since
i've already indexed these devices for
thing
device shadow connectivity and groups
the status already shows is
active for each if you haven't already
indexed your fleet
click the manage indexing button on the
upper right this will take you to the
fleet indexing portion of the console
again you can watch the getting started
with fleet indexing video
if you need help scrolling down
we arrive at the custom search fields
this is where you choose to include
data fields relevant to your application
firmware version and battery level would
be two
typical examples in my case i've created
a serial number attribute for each thing
and i want to include that as mentioned
earlier
the device shadows report the firmware
version and the accelerometer readings
and i want this data in the fleet hub
application too well at least the z-axis
of the accelerometer readings
finally most of the device shadows have
a custom
last seen timestamp and i want to
include that too
i'll explain that in more detail later
you'll know you're ready to progress
when all of your indexing statuses show
up as active and your custom fields are
configured
click next in the final step
we need to create or select an existing
iem service role
i'll go with the default of create we
need to give the application a name
and then click create application
creation can take
up to a few minutes with the
application created we now need to click
into it
and then click add users remember that
fleet hub uses
sso not iam so your operations are
distinct from your development
from the list of sso users select those
users who should have access to your
application
in my case just me click add selected
user
to launch the new application click on
the application url
at this point if you have not logged in
via sso it will ask you to do so
since i'm already logged in it will take
me straight into the application
by default fleet hub lands on the device
list
view of the dashboard we can see all of
the nine things that were registered in
my account
with all six tcpip mqtt devices
currently in a connected state
as laurawan is a connectionless protocol
and doesn't use mqtt
mylorawan devices will always appear
disconnected
and without a last connection timestamp
since all the mqtt devices are currently
connected
none have a disconnect reason by default
the thing type and thin groups of each
device are displayed
and then we see the four custom fields
we configured earlier
serial number of each device
accelerometer z-axis
for each of the six devices with an
accelerometer
firmware version for each device that
reports it and our last
scene custom field the accelerometer
z-axis
is measured in units of g-force a value
of one denotes that the device is the
correct way up
flat on the desk we'll use this later
for alarms
last scene is the last time sensor
readings were received from the device
as distinct from connection time aws iot
core for lorawan devices typically
require a lambda function to decode
their binary payload into json
this lambda is also convenient for
dumping device status into the thing
shadow
such as the firmware version and
accelerometer z-axis
seen here additionally the lambda is a
convenient place to record the timestamp
of the last received payload
by generating the last scene field in
this way
we can get visibility of lorawan device
health
into fleet hub the dashboard also offers
a summary view
of the fleet by clicking on summary we
can see rolled up statistics for our
fleet
total number of devices total number of
connected devices
devices by thing type and devices by
thin group
this makes it really easy to monitor
devices and their state
that's all for this demo to recap i
created my fleet hub web
application in just a few steps and saw
how it leveraged fleet indexing to do a
lot of the initial leg work
using sso i could add users to my fleet
hub application
even if they're not iam users in the
next video
we'll walk through how to manage your
devices using fleet hub
we'll use fleet hub jobs and fleet hub
alarms
to learn more visit the aws iot device
management web page
